title: Instituto Butantan
text:
Instituto Butantan (in modern <a href="Portuguese%20language">Portuguese</a>, Instituto Butantã, ) is a Brazilian <a href="biologic%20medical%20product">biologic</a> research center located in Butantã, in the western part of the city of São Paulo, Brazil. Instituto Butantan is a public institution affiliated with the <a href="S%C3%A3o%20Paulo%20%28state%29">São Paulo</a> State Secretariat of <a href="Health">Health</a> and considered one of the major scientific centers in the world. Butantan is the largest immunobiologicals and biopharmaceuticals producer in Latin America (and one of the largest in the world). It is world-renowned for its collection of venomous snakes, as well as those of venomous lizards, <a href="spider">spider</a>s, <a href="insect">insect</a>s and <a href="scorpion">scorpion</a>s. By extracting the reptiles' and insects' venoms, the Institute develops antivenoms and medicines against many diseases, which include tuberculosis, rabies, tetanus and diphtheria.
History.
The Institute was founded by the Brazilian <a href="physician">physician</a> and biomedical scientist <a href="Vital%20Brazil">Vital Brazil</a> in 1901, according to <a href="Pasteur%20Institute">Pasteur Institute</a> paradigm, i.e., by combining in the same institution <a href="medical%20research">medical research</a>, the transfer of the results to society as health products, and self-financing through this later activity. Its foundation was a reaction to the outbreak of <a href="bubonic%20plague">bubonic plague</a> in the city of <a href="Santos%2C%20S%C3%A3o%20Paulo">Santos</a>. It is internationally renowned for its research on <a href="venom%20%28poison%29">venomous</a> animals; it was visited by <a href="Theodore%20Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a> in 1912. It is also a state-supported producer of <a href="vaccine">vaccine</a>s against many <a href="infectious%20diseases">infectious diseases</a>, such as <a href="rabies">rabies</a>, <a href="hepatitis">hepatitis</a>, <a href="botulism">botulism</a>, <a href="tetanus">tetanus</a>, <a href="diphtheria">diphtheria</a>, <a href="pertussis">pertussis</a> and <a href="tuberculosis">tuberculosis</a>, as well as polyvalent and monovalent <a href="antivenom">antivenom</a>s against the bites of <a href="snakes">snakes</a>, <a href="lizards">lizards</a>, <a href="bees">bees</a>, <a href="scorpion">scorpion</a>s and <a href="spider">spider</a>s (which, historically were first developed in the beginning of the 20th century by Dr. Vital Brazil and his coworkers). Among the distinguished scientists at the institute were biochemists <a href="Karl%20Slotta">Karl Slotta</a> and <a href="Heinz%20Fraenkel-Conrat">Heinz Fraenkel-Conrat</a>, pioneers in the study of progesterone, estriol, and medical use of venom, from 1935 to 1948.
A fire in 2010 destroyed the collection facility, which maintained one of the largest collections of venomous animals in the world, comprising around 80,000 snake specimens, and an estimated 450,000 spiders and scorpions.
The name of the institute comes from "Butantã", a district in the west zone of São Paulo. "Butantã" itself is a <a href="Tupian%20languages">Tupi</a> word meaning "crushed soil".
Education and research.
The Institute develops basic and applied biomedical research in many areas, including <a href="molecular%20biology">molecular biology</a>, <a href="immunology">immunology</a> and <a href="epidemiology">epidemiology</a> and has a graduate research training program in collaboration with other institutions, in the areas of biotechnology and <a href="infectology">infectology</a>. Besides its research laboratories, production units and specialized library, it operates an animal breeding center for providing subjects for research and production of sera. The Instituto Butantan also operate the "Hospital Vital Brazil", a specialist hospital that offers free treatment for poisonous animal stings and bites. The institute also accepts donations of serpents, arthropods and other animals captured by the public and by a network of collaborating centers and individuals.

Important Brazilian scientists who have worked in the Butantan Institute are: <a href="Vital%20Brazil">Vital Brazil</a>, <a href="Afr%C3%A2nio%20Pomp%C3%ADlio%20Gastos%20do%20Amaral">Afrânio Pompílio Gastos do Amaral</a>, <a href="Isaias%20Raw">Isaias Raw</a>, <a href="Samuel%20Pessoa">Samuel Pessoa</a>, <a href="Willy%20Be%C3%A7ak">Willy Beçak</a>. The Institute has strong collaborative ties with the <a href="Pasteur%20Institute">Pasteur Institute</a>, <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, France, and with the <a href="Oswaldo%20Cruz%20Foundation">Oswaldo Cruz Foundation</a>, <a href="Rio%20de%20Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>.
Production.
The Butantan Institute is the largest producer in <a href="Latin%20America">Latin America</a> (and one of the largest in the world) of immunobiologicals and biopharmaceuticals. In 2001 it produced ca. doses of vaccines and vials of hyperimmune sera. The institute is responsible for the production of 90% of the vaccines used in Brazil. The institute contains a venom farm where researchers milk around a thousand snakes for their <a href="venom">venom</a> which is used to make <a href="antivenom">antivenom</a>s and for medical research.

Public activities.
The Butantan Institute is one of the major touristic and educational attractions in a vast park area in the city section of <a href="Butant%C3%A3%20%28district%20of%20S%C3%A3o%20Paulo%29">Butantã</a> in São Paulo. It has a <a href="serpentarium">serpentarium</a>, a historical museum, a biological museum, and a museum of microbiology. The venom farm is a major attraction and visitors can see the snakes housed in representations of their natural environments. The park also contains rare tree types.
Butantan Foundation.
The Fundação Butantan is a non-profit corporation established in 1984 by Prof. Willy Beçak to use more efficiently public funds and capital investments made by the Ministry of Health for the production of immunobiologicals. The Foundation reinvests part of the proceeds to build new facilities for new products. Part of the funds are used in the Institute for research and cultural activities, as well as to provide its workers with meals and basic food supplies.
2010 fire.
On May 15, 2010, a fire almost burned down the laboratory and destroyed the Institute's entire collection of snake specimens (approximately 85,000 specimens preserved with <a href="formaldehyde">formaldehyde</a> and stored in 70% <a href="ethanol">ethanol</a>) and ca. 450,000–500,000 specimens of scorpions and spiders (also stored in ethanol). It was one of the largest collections of snakes in the world. Over 90 years of research were lost.
The fire started at and was brought under control by a crew of 50 firemen an hour and a half later. News reports have claimed that the facility was not prepared for a fire, not having a <a href="fire%20alarm">fire alarm</a> or <a href="fire%20sprinkler%20system">sprinkler system</a>. Police are investigating the fire which has been described by curator Francisco Luís Franco as "a loss for humanity". None of the live animals or people at the institute was harmed by the fire.
